Award.AwardTitle: Representations of Finite Groups and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal focuses on several important problems in representation theory of finite groups and its applications. Many of these problems come up naturally -- some long-standing and playing a central role -- in group representation theory, and others are motivated by various applications. The proposal ties together different areas of mathematics, such as finite groups and algebraic groups, finite permutation group theory, group cohomology, combinatorics, operator algebras, and algebraic geometry, with the main unifying ingredient being the representation theory. The PI will study several problems along the lines of the local-global principle, including the Alperin weight conjecture, Brauer's height zero conjecture, and some further conjectures concerning rationality and divisibility properties of complex and Brauer characters of finite groups. The PI will also continue his long-term project to classify modular representations of finite quasisimple groups of low dimension. He will then apply his results to achieve significant progress on a number of applications, including Waring-type problems for quasisimple groups, Aschbacher's conjecture on subgroup lattices, the Kollar-Larsen problem on exterior powers (with application in algebraic geometry), and the Guralnick-Holt conjecture on second cohomology groups for finite groups and their presentations, and representations of finite quasisimple groups with special properties (with application in the subgroup structure of finite simple groups).

The main area of research in this proposal is group representation theory. The concept of a group in mathematics grew out ofthe notion of symmetry. The symmetries of an object in nature or science are encoded by a group, and this group carries a lot of important information about the structure of the object itself. The representation theory allows one to study groups via their actions on vector spaces which model the ways they arise in the real world. It has fascinated mathematicians for more than a century and has many important applications in physics and chemistry, particularly in quantum mechanics and in the theory of elementary particles. Finite groups and their representations have already proved valuable in coding theory and cryptography, and are expected to continue to play an important role in the modern world of computers and digital communications. The investigator's research will lead to important advances in understanding the representation theory of finite groups and help achieve significant progress in a number of its applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes of the research grant DMS-1839351

The NSF grant DMS-1201374 (DMS-1839351 after transfer from the University of Arizona to Rutgers University) focuses on several important problems in representation theory of finite groups, and their applications in finite permutation group theory, group cohomology, combinatorics, and algebraic geometry. Among the major outcomes of the PI's research  within this grant, we mention

-- proof of a generalized version of Gluck-Wolf theorem, published in Annals of Math. 2013. Together with another paper of Navarro and Spaeth, this theorem gives a reduction of the height zero conjecture stated by R. Brauer in 1955, one of the main conjectures in the modular representation theory of finite groups, to quasisimple groups;

-- proof of a conjecture of J. Thompson (1981), published in Forum of Math. Pi 2016. This also yields an absolute upper bound for the G. Tian's alpha-invariant for the action of any finite group on the projective space P^n;

-- proof of adequacy of most of linear groups in low dimension, published in two papers, Algebra Number Theory 2015 and  J. Europ. Math. Soc. 2017. The notion of adequacy was introduced by J. Thorne and plays an important role in many modularity and automorphy lifting theorems in number theory;

-- proof of polynomial growth of modular representations of finite simple groups, published in Duke Math. J. 2012;

-- solution of Brauer's problems 11 and 12 (recognition of abelian Sylow subgroups, respectively nilpotent and abelian Hall subgroups, using character table), published in three papers in J. Algebra 2014, 2015, and Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 2016;

-- proof of Gow's conjecture on Sylow 2-subgroups of real finite groups, published in Adv. Math. 2016;

-- construction of natural McKay correspondences (between the p'-degree characters of the group G and those of the normalizer of a Sylow p-subgroup in G) in a number of cases, published in Algebra Number Theory 2014, and IMRN 2017;

-- proof of a generalization of the celebrated characterization of solvable groups of J. Thompson, published in Crelle's journal 2015.

The PI's research within this grant has led to a better understanding of basic properties, in particular linear representations and also permutation representations, of finite groups, especially finite groups of Lie type, long-standing conjectures about them, and their interrelations with other areas of mathematics. It has also led to significant advances in a number of applications in structural and cohomological group theory, combinatorics, Galois theory, arithmetic of curves, algebraic geometry, and number theory.

Results obtained within this grant have helped train four graduate students, all of whom have defended their Ph. D. Theses under the PI's supervision in 2013, 2016, 2017, and 2018. One of them, Mrs. Schaeffer Fry, accepted a postdoctoral position at the Michigan State University, then went on to a tenure-track Assistant Professorship at the Metro State University Denver, CO, and has just been promoted to Associate Professor with tenure in Summer 2018. Mr. Trefethen is currently at a postdoctoral position at the Department of Mathematics, William & Mary College. After graduation, Ms. Lee accepted a position with Samsung, and Mr. Rossi accepted a 3-year
postdoctoral position at the SUNY Binghamton.

The PI's results have been lectured at many national and international conferences, including

-- an invited 45-min lecture at the International Congress of Mathematicians 2018, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Aug. 1--9, 2018;

-- Bernoulli Lecture, Centre Interfacultaire Bernoulli, EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland, Oct. 20, 2016;

-- London Algebra Colloquium, City University London, London, UK, April 2, 2015;

-- a plenary address at the 8th Congress of Vietnamese Mathematicians, Nhatrang, Vietnam, Aug. 10--14, 2013; and

-- two main lectures at the Annual Meeting of the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) Priority Programme on Representation Theory SPP 1388, Bad Boll, Germany, March 25--28, 2013.
Some of these results have also been used in graduate courses taught by the PI at the University of Arizona, summer schools in Hanoi, and Number Theory and Arithmetic Geometry RTG Workshop, University of California, Berkeley, CA,  April 30--May 4, 2018.
